question: It's an accident. It means the flower developed a virus early in the bulb stage. The flaws create the unusual coloring. Of course. What kind of price range are you looking for?
answer: Well, it's for my parent's anniversary. They don't know I'm coming. I just want it to be beautiful. Can you just do whatever you think looks best?

question: I'll need a few minutes.
answer: Take your time, please. And thank you.

question: That should be some surprise.
For your parents.
Which one is it?
Anniversary.
Wow. Okay. I think I have an idea. Something classic.
Straight back, on the left. It's unisex.
The Baldwins.
We had dinner with them three years ago. You talked about your parent's anniversary.
The opening doesn't work.
She shouldn't have the same dream as Franklin. He's the antagonist.
No it wasn't.
answer: Well, it wasn't mine. It couldn't be; it's too stupid.

question: Why do you do that? why do you have to get personal?
answer: It's not personal, it's a fact.

question: It's personal. You don't argue logically. You attack. Bring the right foot back even with the left, buttocks raised high.... ...you have to have reasons, to support your argument... ...flattening the back so the body forms a triangle.
answer: I can't listen to you anymore. It makes me physically sick.

question: Relax the crown of the head toward the floor. Draw the hips away from the hands, len--gthening the spine. And press the heels toward the floor.
answer: This a serious class. No pigs allowed. Okay?

question: Virge. You're hallucinating.
What it is about horses? I ask you. Is it the strength? The beauty? The fearlessness? The grace? Of course. But there's something else. Something in the eyes.
Yes?
answer: There appears to be a problem with your card.

question: You take Visa?
answer: I was acting on instructions from your business manager.

question: My business manager?
How many think if they run, they'll be found?
Good.
AMSTERDAM!?
Tom.
Anybody can be a Tom.
answer: You gotta make your own opportunities. This ain't a rehearsal.

question: Tom.
What are you doing in Amsterdam?
answer: Only what I have to do to get Benedict off our backs.

question: Be careful, Danny. Please.
It's the same. I'm distracted.
It's not your fault.
answer: I keep trying to figure out what I did wrong. How did he find us?

question: Danny, don't keep thinking about it.
answer: I did something wrong. He should never have found us.

question: I'll call you tomorrow. I love you.
You're not going to believe this.
We don't have line-of-sight.
What?
Listen
answer: It's like blood in the water for these guys.

question: If they think you're slipping, you won't even see it coming.
answer: But hey--thanks. I need some air.

question: The Swinging Priest?
Crazy Larry.
Robinov's Revenge?
The Soft Shoulder.
Baker's Dozen.
Hell in a Handbasket.
answer: Can't train the cat that quickly.

question: I can't have my wife watch me hauled off in handcuffs again.
answer: It's always about you, isn't it?

question: This like running toward a cliff. Speaking of which, how's Isabel?
answer: I have no idea what you're talking about.

question: You get the tattoo removed?
answer: Given its location, my doctor advised against it.

question: What are you doing?
Counterfeiting? Me? I have to tell you, it's not something I condone. It's cheating.
There's no subtlety to it.
No one I know...
answer: I can't imagine anything like that.

question: Not bad.
Diego's people?
Well. Congratulations.

Let's discuss, briefly and to begin, with the category of "thieves", as distinguished from the larger category of what might be termed "hardened" criminals. The highest level, "master thieves," if you will, is a very small world. Between six and ten high-level crews are operating in Europe at any given time. Worldwide, no more than twenty. The most famous, Gaspar LeMarc, is either dead or retired, and the expectation is that no one will replace him. The good news is the trend is toward their extinction. For example Their egos demand constant praise, and they embellish their exploits to anyone who will listen. They tell their own stories endlessly, provided of course, they are talking to a fellow thief or an intimate. Those who interact with them on a personal level are relegated to positions of total servitude, with no chance for growth or freedom. Their lives are treated as secondary. Many of them suffer from depression. It's a crime for which there is no law, and yet causes untold damage. That's impossible!
answer: Thanks for coming. We can really use your help on this one.

question: I hope the scene hasn't been contaminated. No forced entry.
answer: Not that we can find. We can't figure out how they disabled the alarm. We thought maybe they tried to short it out somehow.

question: No, that would have triggered the system. They had to have known the code.
answer: We considered that, but the mark swears that nobody in the world knew the code except him. He programmed the last seven steps of the system himself. He set it and never left the house again. When he dies, we'll probably have to physically cut all the power lines to the house to get it off line.

question: There are other ways to get the code. Closed loop. Redundant servers. Titanium encasement. Not bad.
Uh...well, they probably set up in a house across the canal and watched him type the code in through a pair of binoculars.
answer: Actually, I don't know about that.

question: That's why they probably set up over there--
It's where the crossbow bolt hit.
Ever heard of Franz Schuman?
They would have fired from that roof. Through this open window.
answer: From that roof, through this window? Nobody could make a shot like that.

question: Not a cop, anyway.
Sorry. Your friend downstairs put me in a bad mood.
answer: He's an idiot. You shouldn't let him bother you.

question: Yes. You're right. When did he get up and notice the certificate was gone?
answer: The alarm woke him at 4:2O am.

question: But the alarm would have been--
There was someone else.
I'm not quitting.
Who are you? Apparently, you can do whatever you want with him.
answer: Oh no. I just need to speak with him. To get some information.

question: We've been on him for six hours. Our best stuff. In mind terms, we've been torturing this guy.
answer: I'm sure. I only need a moment, then I'll be out of your way.

question: I don't have twenty-four hours. They're there now. They'll lead me to him.
answer: He said we can't leave until tomorrow because of liability issues and he needs a document.

question: Yes.
Let's share a car.
answer: That would be nice. Thank you.

question: Last time I checked titles like that went out with a little number I like to call the French Revolution--
What?
answer: His title. It's Spanish. Mother's cousin.

question: He may be the greatest thief in Europe. He may have slept with half of the EU. He may be a Casanova with the soul of a starving artist. It doesn't matter. There's something he cares about. There's something he can't live without.
answer: You are worse than Sampras. You should be paying me. Put them on the veranda and get them a drink. I'll be right up. Rusty.

question: Other way around.
answer: Are you sure? Usually I'm so good at that. This is Edmund. Edmund. Rusty. Danny.

question: Nice to meet you. Edmund. You a tennis pro?
answer: Sadly, I can't show you my favorite painting of all -- a Degas that used to hang right there -- because it was stolen recently.

question: Listen, Francois--
We came here for the Vanderspeigle certificate--
Your Degas is worth three times that. You want your painting back, you're going to have to trade.
answer: You actually expect me to believe that you are in possession of my Degas? You are living in a...in a bubble.

question: That's not how I want to go.
answer: No. Very theatrical of you...asking to meet here. Like we're spies meeting to do an exchange.

question: Why are you doing this to us?
This is a game for you. For us it's survival. Are you that bored? I mean...
answer: No. I wouldn't do that. No... The truth is...I made a bet. Or maybe a better word is a "wager".

question: What kind of wager?
answer: A gentlemen's wager with a friend of mine -- my mentor. A few months ago we were at his winter place in Nicaragua and another guest referred to me as "the greatest thief in the world." I didn't object, obviously, but my mentor fell silent. Later I asked him about it. He said if I really wanted to say I was the best thief...I'd have to prove I was better than the eleven of you. Sorry. 163. Before you were found. Yes, 163 million is a lot of money. It attracts attention. So, in a way, you brought this problem with me on yourselves. You're victims of your own success.

question: Here's what I'm going to do. You tell me the name of your mentor. I'll call him up and I'll tell him that you're the greatest thief in the world...that I accept that to be true.... And in return...you leave us alone, let us go about our business. How about that?
answer: He said you'd probably say something like that -- but he said you'd probably have your fingers crossed when you said it. So in this situation -- for the purposes of my wager -- words aren't good enough. I have to prove this on the ground.

question: This mentor of yours...was he a good thief in his day?
I'm going to need surveillance on both hotels, phone taps, room bugs, people in the lobby and by every exit.
If I had to guess I'd say I'll need at least 25 people, a dozen vehicles...and an on-call air unit.
Okay, one more thing, and this is crucial
Okay. Good. Now what time am I meeting Captain Giordano?
No, what time?
I see...so...you've spoken with the Pope and he's okay with autographing my breasts?
What am I looking at?
answer: A TR354 infra red motion detection system. It's the gold standard.

question: Saul and Linus back yet?
No?
Jesus, Robert. I could've killed you.
I hope so. What are you doing in my room?
answer: I thought maybe we could get some coffee.

question: No, thanks.
answer: Okay, how about a two week trip to Zanzibar?

question: Please don't.
answer: Fine, coffee then. Whatever you say.

question: Why do I want to have coffee with you?
answer: How should I know? sorry about your mom.

question: She hated you.
answer: Well, she was nice enough to hide it from me. Some people can't even do that.

question: She hated everybody. You'll never get it by the way.

You'll think you've got it, you'll be so close that you'll be able to taste it and then this guy, the Night Fox or whoever he is, will just take it -- right out of your hand -- just like he did in Amsterdam. He's as good as LeMarc.

...reason to believe these men... ...are going to try to steal the Coronation Egg when it is actually put on display next week. I need official authorization to surveil and pursue these suspected criminals on Italian soil.
And I'll need substantial resources from your department. Can I count on that?
So, Captain, what do you think of my skirt?
answer: I think it's very beautiful. Why, don't you like it?

question: I don't usually call for a second date. For you I make an exception.

I think it's good that we talk. You see, you should stop following me. You're wasting your time. I'm going to let you go first and get caught. Then they will increase the security even more, and then I will steal the Egg. Then Lemarc can make his decision.
Confident? This is a very American word. I am arrogant. There's a difference.
answer: Doesn't matter if you're that good. Are you that good?

question: I can move objects with my mind. You don't believe it?
Are you done stirring your sugar?
answer: That's fantastic. Listen, I appreciate the call, and, best of luck.

question: Danny. I'm serious. Sit down, please.
answer: You're telekinetic, is that what you're telling me?

question: We both did. I'm exhausted. Hi, this isn't official business. Actually, I'm here on vacation. But I was sitting in a cafe this afternoon, near the Piazza Navona and...the police were chasing someone on foot. I was just wondering if you caught him or...do you know anything about that case? Oh... Excuse me...
Um...Did I...? I think I saw you...yesterday.
The police were chasing you.
answer: You sure your eyes aren't broken?

question: I'm quite sure it was you.
answer: Well, then I'm not gonna argue. Can I buy you a coffee?

question: Hello.
answer: We've got to stop meeting like this.

question: What are they talking about all the time?!
answer: Soccer. He doesn't like Naples....thinks they're a bunch of...sissies. Can I ask you a question? Will you come to Zanzibar with me on Friday?

question: What do you want?
I don't even think Toulour can get it now.
answer: If he gets it, we'll let you arrest us. If we get it, you come away with me to Zanzibar--

question: What is your obsession with Zanzibar?!
answer: Do you want to make the bet or not?

question: "Someone he knows. Someone he trusts...." "Someone he knows...."
answer: What about someone he doesn't know but trusts?

question: For instance?
answer: I'm talking about you know who, who looks an awful lot like you know who...

question: Ms. Roberts! Ms. Roberts! Why did you come back to Rome so soon!!
Was it to see Topher?
Topher Grace!! Your co-star!! Is that why you're here?!
answer: Oh. No. I came to -- to see the--

question: Where's Danny?
Danny, your husband!!
I can't do this.
I'm not an actress, Danny! And I don't look like her!
answer: You do, Tess. You really do. I never told you that before, but it's true.

question: Come on And my... And my ears. Anybody who sees my ears is going to know instantly.
When did that happen?
answer: We just found out. I arranged a private showing for tomorrow morning before we open the show to the public.

question: I don't understand, why do you have to disable any of the systems--
answer: Because she might want to get close to the egg, got right up here and look at it. And I'm not going to embarrass myself or this institution by telling her she can't.

question: She's an actress, Giovanni, not the Pope.
answer: Do you realize how much free publicity we'll get for this museum, just because she because she decided to come by and look at the egg? She's even agreed to do a photo shoot for us promoting the museum.

question: That's exactly the sort of thing... ...that the people I'm after will exploit. Okay, fine. You want to shut down half the electronic system, let me post eight cops in the room...
answer: Are you crazy? That's worse than....you want me to treat her like a criminal? Look, if you need to do something to reinforce security during her visit, fine. But it's got to be out of sight. And it can't effect Julia in any way. Are we clear?

question: Where is he?
answer: There. I took a look at the interrogation scene.

question: Why?
It clarifies everything.
answer: He said it's too on the nose.

question: What's he, the head of the studio? What's he ever written?
What?
What! How did you-- You moron! You said you were watching him the whole time!
answer: I was! I mean, I used the bathroom once, but it was quick. You lost him yesterday!

question: I'm sorry.
I have to go. Right now. I have to leave the country. It could be a while. A month. Maybe more. Isabel turns to look at Rusty. She can barely see the outline of his face in the darkness.
answer: What are you saying? What the hell are you saying? Where are you going?

question: I can't tell you. Isabel stares at his dark face.
answer: When people start talking the way you're talking there are only two possibilities

question: You knew what I was the day you met me, Isabel.
We can talk about it when I get back.
answer: No, Robert. I have to tell you something.

question: What is it?
answer: I'm taking the job. I'm moving to Amsterdam. He doesn't respond for a moment.

question: I can't have this conversation right now. Please, Isabel. I have to get out of here. I love you. He kisses her then leaves.
answer: You want to walk? I know how you're planning to do it. I know Julia's visit is the key.

question: Who's Julia?
answer: LeMarc knew when to get out. He just quit...with his perfect record intact. Now he's a legend. Don't do this.

question: LeMarc quit because he was 75 years old, Isabel. He was tired. His doctor told him if he didn't start taking it easy he was going to have another heart attack. You're dramatizing it.
answer: You don't know why LeMarc retired, any better than I do. You have no idea.

question: Actually, I do. I know exactly why.
He told me.
A little.
Ten years ago.
For six months.
answer: You-- You knew LeMarc? You knew LeMarc and never told me? That's the worst thing you've ever done to me. Nobody knows more about LeMarc than me. How could you do that?

question: I couldn't tell you, then.
answer: Really awful. Then why aren't you as good as Toulour? I don't want to arrest you, Robert. I really don't. But I will if you make me. I will if you go for that egg. So many times, I waited. You can't do that to a person.

question: Isabel--
Hello? Hey! I got your room number from McCormick, I hope you don't mind. This is great. Do you have the adjoining room?
Oh. Hey. I saw the rough cut of YOU ALWAYS, YOU NEVER. It's so awesome. Congratulations.
It was just like a dub of a lo-rez output, but I could totally see what you were doing. I think you might win again. Seriously.
It really actually looked like you were blind. How did you do that? What is it like, an on-set thing, or was it digital?

You can tell me, I won't tell a soul. Because if you say it's instinctual, I'm quitting right now. Seriously. The way you parted your hair? That was so connected. And that scene with the matches? And when you find out who your real grandmother is and run through the rain and find her on the porch and touch her face? Man, that was...you gotta tell Steven how much I loved it.
So what are you doing?
answer: I'm, uh, getting ready to go out...

question: I mean next. What movie are you doing next?
answer: I...I'm having trouble deciding what to do next.

question: Is Danny working?
Oh, no. Is something wrong? Have you two...
I'm so sorry. I'm so sorry.
answer: No. we're absolutely fine, he's just--

question: I've got to stop asking people about their spouses, it's like always a mistake--
Listen, I won't say a word. Seriously. I'm rooting for you guys, you know that. This is your private business and I totally respect that. No more Danny questions from me.
answer: Thank you. He's fine. Danny's fine. He's working.

question: Julia -- unless you have any objections -- Wen and his crew set up for the publicity stills. I was thinking maybe we could get you and Topher into some "You Always You Never" hats and t-shirts for the shoot--
So stupid! Idiot. Maybe we could put some posters in the background--
answer: I don't think we want to be so obvious--

question: Hey, J Ro, why the quick exit?
answer: I...uh, I have to take some pills. Aspirin. I get headaches.

question: Yeah, well, with everything thing you've been going through I can see how you'd need something.
Right. I've never taken aspirin in my life, ever. Can you believe that?
For me, it's like a control thing.

Oh, yeah... I'll start with him. When people think of Italy they think of food, wine, the Renaissance. They don't realize Italy has the scariest prisons in the civilized world. You know why? They're all leftover from the Middle Ages. They're worse than dirty; they're damp. They're like caves.
Testify against the others in the Benedict case.

Sure you can. You'll get a year, maybe two. The Italian charges will be dropped. You and the others will be extradited to the US this afternoon. Think about those prisons. Think about living there for twenty years, getting out when you're fifty. What a catch you'll be.
Why didn't you tell me?
Why not?
answer: Because you're not an actress. You wouldn't have been so real.

question: I thought you were going to jail.
So you don't think I'm a good actress.
I'm a good liar.
He...
That was...okay, so I'm not a good liar. So what. You're good enough for both of us.
I hate you.
This will ruin me.
answer: No, it won't. Not if you come to Zanzibar.

question: What is it with Zanzibar?
answer: It's where LeMarc is. That one's ours. We can be there in three hours. Don't you want to meet him? He wants to meet you.

question: You're asking me to turn my back on my whole life.
I'm a cop. That's who I am.
answer: You're only a cop because your father was a thief.

question: Who died in a Russian jail.
What does that mean?
answer: It means you should meet LeMarc.

question: I've got an idea for another Dominique story.
answer: Can we finish this one first?

question: Just let me tell it to you.
It's like three sentences.
answer: I'm serious; you're asking too much.

question: Is opposite him. They are both being served for lunch by a JACKETED WAITER, whose face is continually obscured. That's the exact figure, I'm pretty sure.
So we're clean?
I'll take your word.
These grudges, they're awful. Nobody wine.
answer: As soon as someone retaliates, the situation is out of control.

question: This way, there's no need for retaliation. Why would there be?
More than plenty. It's just a matter of sharing.
